awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Individual and Collective Dynamics of  Marangoni Surface Tension Effects between Particles
awd_abstract_narration:
The principal goal of this research is to investigate the motion of active particles at fluidic interfaces due to a gradient of surface tension stemming from the discharge of a surface-active agent, a surface reaction, or from the release of heat by the particle. Powered by converting chemical energy into mechanical work, these self-propelled "Marangoni" particles, both at the individual level and as a collection, can bring to bear functionalities that resemble those of biological organisms. The findings of this study will determine the guiding principles for designing miniature self-propelled particles, which can lead to transformative innovations in robotics, microfluidics, and biomedical engineering. These tiny surfing robots can potentially execute missions that are currently very difficult or even impossible to accomplish. The results of this project will also give rise to the development of active self-assembly techniques, which can be used for rapid fabrication of small-scale structured materials. Further, the outcome of this research will shed light on the role of self-generated Marangoni stresses in the colonization and survival of antibiotic-resistant infectious bacteria living at fluidic interfaces. The new insight provided by these studies can thus facilitate the design of more effective antibiotics. Graduate students supported by the project will gain advanced training in fluid dynamics, transport and interfacial phenomena, and high-performance simulations. Educational modules on Marangoni propulsion and flow-driven self-assembly at interfaces will be created and showcased during outreach activities, in addition to being integrated into the existing engineering courses. Active involvement of underrepresented minority and female students will be pursued via educational and outreach activities.

This research will establish a fundamental understanding of the Marangoni-driven motion of active particles alone and in groups, which appear in various contexts ranging from robotics and manufacturing to biology and medicine. New knowledge will be created by introducing a comprehensive numerical-theoretical-experimental framework to examine the hydrodynamics of self-propelled interface-bound active particles. The successful completion of this project will lead to the development of a physics-based speed and stability charts for Marangoni surfers that serves as engineering guidelines for tailoring the system parameters to elicit the desired performance characteristics in a variety of applications. Additionally, the outcome of this study will advance the state-of-the-art in multi-physics computational analysis of particle-laden interfacial flows by developing a high-performance simulation technique capable of capturing the intricate interplay between the motion of the active particles, transport of released species or heat, and interface deformation and dynamics. The specific objectives of this project are: (i) characterizing the Marangoni propulsion of single particles in unbounded domains; (ii) investigating the influence of confinement on the propulsion dynamics of particles; (iii) analyzing the translational and rotational stability of self-propelled surfers; and (iv) exploring the self-assembly and collective surfing of active particles.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we studied the Marangoni-driven motion of active particles straddling the interface between two immiscible fluids (see Fig. 1). The transport of interface-trapped particles due to self-generated surface tension gradients appears frequently in man-made and biological systems. Arguably, the most basic human-made example is the soap boat, where the gradual dissolution of a soap piece attached to the back of the boat creates a surface tension asymmetry that leads to the self-propulsion of the craft. Miniature analogs of this very simple Marangoni surfer have been created recently with the ultimate goal of designing programmable surfing robots for microfluidic manipulation, self-assembly, and targeted drug delivery. These tiny Marangoni surfers can potentially execute missions that are currently very difficult or even impossible to accomplish.

The Marangoni propulsion phenomenon emerges in biological systems as well. For instance, there are water-walking insects, such as Dianous (a rove beetle) and Velia (a small water strider), that secrete surface-active materials to boost their walking speed in emergency situations. The Marangoni propulsion has also been reported as the primary mechanism for the rapid interfacial migration of bacterial swarms towards nutrient-rich regions for further colonization. These studies have suggested that the signaling molecules exuded by the surface-associated bacteria such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa are also active agents that locally alter the surface tension. Fighting these infectious microrganisms by antibiotics often involves hampering their Marangoni-driven collective dynamics responsible for their colonization.

This project created new knowledge by introducing a comprehensive numerical-theoretical-experimental framework to examine the individual and collective dynamics of active Marangoni surfers. Specifically, using theory and high-performance numerical simulation (see Fig. 2), we uncovered the mechanisms underlying the propulsion behavior and stability (both translational and rotational) of fast-propelling Marangoni surfers in unbounded domains and under confinement (see Figs. 3, 4, and 5). We also demonstrated how the fundamental knowledge gained from our theoretical, numerical, and experimental investigations can be translated into the design and fabrication of a self-powered, remotely controlled surfing robot capable of traversing the air-water interface using surface tension modification for propulsion and steering (see Fig. 6).

The findings of this project were disseminated through peer-reviewed articles published in respected scientific journals, such as Journal of Fluid Mechanics, Physical Review Fluids, Physics of Fluids, Journal Fluids Engineering, International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer, Journal of Heat Transfer, and Bioinspiration & Biomimetics. Furthermore, the results of this project were presented at several conferences, including the 2018 American Mathematical Society Fall Central Sectional Meeting, 2019 Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics Conference on Applications of Dynamical Systems, and Seeking Simplicity in Complex Fluids Workshop at Princeton University in 2020. Additional eight presentations were given at the 2017, 2018, 2019, and 2021 annual meetings of the American Physical Society Division of Fluid Dynamics. The outcomes of this project were also communicated to nonspecialists by dissemination via popular science and social media.

One Ph.D. student, from the beginning, and another Ph.D. student (who initially was a Master's student) were involved in this project. The students complimented each other's activities and learned from their experiences. The project supported the attendance of both students at the annual meetings of the American Physical Society's Division of Fluid Dynamics, which is the world's premier conference in the field of fluid mechanics. The students' attendance played a critical role in their professional development. The Ph.D. student who was involved in the project from the beginning successfully defended his dissertation and graduated in May 2021. The other Ph.D. student is expected to graduate in the summer of 2022.

During the course of this project, a lab demonstration entitled "Motorless Mini Boats" was designed and regularly presented to middle school students during their visit to Michigan Tech. Also, a Hispanic high-school student was hosted for a week-long internship in the summer of 2018, and a community college student from Wayne County Community College was hosted for a seven-week research experience in the summer of 2021. After finishing the internship, the high-school student sent a hand-written note stating that the internship made him consider mechanical engineering as his college major of choice.
